awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Microwave Auto-Oscillators Driven by Pure Spin Currents
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop and study the characteristics of microwave magnetic auto-oscillators driven by pure spin currents.
The intellectual merit is a deeper understanding of phenomena induced in nanoscale magnetic systems by spin currents, which will be facilitated by the new, previously inaccessible structures and geometries of devices driven by spin currents, by the development of advanced magnetic characterization techniques - micro-focus Brillouin Light Spectroscopy and x-ray dichroism microscopy, and by the advances in theoretical understanding of nanoscale magnetic systems.
The broader impacts are enhanced competitiveness of US science/technology, training of specialists for the electronics industry, and general public education. Namely, a new class of microwave auto-oscillators developed in this program will help maintain US leadership in microwave electronics.  Undergraduate and graduate students will be exposed to the modern methods of fabrication and characterization of spintronic nanostructures, and will interact with the leading scientists. Outreach activities including lectures and demonstrations on nanoscience and nanotechnology tailored for K-12 teachers and students will scientifically inform the general public. Student education will be enhanced through the incorporation of theoretical and experimental methods of nanotechnology and spintronics into the graduate and undergraduate curricula.
The main transformative aspect of the proposal will be the development of a qualitatively new type of active spin-based devices where spin currents will be used directly, without being accompanied by charge currents, opening the possibilities for using new types of materials and device geometries.

por.por_cntn:
The program developed and studied the characteristics and possible applications in spintronic and magnonic devices of microwave magnetic auto-oscillators driven by pure spin currents generated by the spin Hall effect. The latter is a physical mechanism that allows the control of spin degree of freedom of electron through its orbital motion, and vice versa.

The intellectual merit of the project is the fundamental understanding of phenomena induced in nanoscale magnetic systems by spin currents, which has been facilitated by the new structures and geometries of devices driven by spin currents accessible to advanced optical magnetic characterization techniques such as micro-focus Brillouin Light Spectroscopy and electronic microwave spectroscopy. Measurements utilizing these advanced techniques have shown that coherent dynamical states induced by spin current are generally enabled by singling out one mode out of the continuous spectrum of dynamical excitations, which can be achieved thanks to the nonlinear dynamical effects, dipolar fields in nanoscale structures, Oersted field of the current, and/or the dependence of the local effective magnetization on spin current. This fundamentally significant general result applies not only to magnetic systems, but to other condensed matter systems with continuous or quasi-continuous excitation spectrum.

The broader impacts were the enhanced competitiveness of US science/technology, training of specialists for the electronics industry, and general public education. Undergraduate and graduate students were exposed to the modern methods of fabrication and characterization of spintronic nanostructures, while interacting with the leading scientists. Outreach activities included demonstrations and hands-on activities tailored for the general public, as well as research experience for high school students.

The main transformative aspect of the proposal was the development of a qualitatively new type of active spin-based devices where spin currents are used directly, without being accompanied by charge currents, opening the possibilities for using new types of materials and device geometries.
